titleStmt.title: The Description of an irish Feast translated al-
most litterally out of the original Irish by Dean

publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: O Rourk's noble Fare shall ne'er be forgot,
By those who were there, or those who were not,
It'S Revells to keep, we sup and we dine
On seven Score Sheep, fat Bullocks & Swine
Usquebaugh to our Feast in Pails was brought up
An hundred at least, & a 1A wooden drinking Vessel. Madder our Cup.
O there is the Sport! we rise with the Light,
In disorderly Sort from snoring all Night,
O how I was trick'd, my Pipe it was broke,
My Pocket was pickt, I lost my new Cloak,
I'm rifl'd, quoth Nell, of Mantle & Kercher
Why then fare them well, the De'el take the Searcher.
Come Harper strike up, but first by your Favour
Boy, give us a Cup, ay, this has some Savour
O Rourk's jolly Boys ne'er dreamt of the Matter
Till rouz'd by the Noise and musical Clatter,
They bounce from their Nest, no longer will tarry
They rise ready drest, without one Ave Mary.
They dance in a round, cutting Capers, & ramping,
A mercy the Ground did not burst with their Stamping,
The Floor is all wet with Leaps & with Jumps,
While the Water & Sweat splish splash, in their Pumps,
Bless you, late & early Laughlin, o Enakin
By my hand you dance rearly, Margery Greenigan
Bring Straw for our Bed, shake it down to our Feet,
Then over us spread the winnowing Sheet,
To shew you I don't flinch, fill the Bowl up again,
Then give us a Pinch of your sneezing 2an irish Name for Woman anglicè Hannah. a Yean.
Good Lord what a Sight, after all their good Cheer,
For People to fight in the midst of their Beer
They rise from their Feast, & hot are their Brains
A Cubit at least the Lenght of their Skeans.
What Stabs & what Cuts, with clatt'ring of Sticks.
What Strokes on the Guts, what basting & Kicks,
With Cudgels of Oaks well harden'd in Flame,
An hundred Heads broke, an hundred struck lame.
You churl, I'll maintain my Father built Lusk.
The Castle of Slane & Carrick, Drumrusk.
The Earl of Kildare, & Moynealta his Brother,
As great as they are, I was nurs'd by their Mother,
Ask that of old Madam? she'll tell you who's who.
As far up as Adam, she knows it is true,
Come down with that Beam, if Cudgels are scarce.
A Blow on the Weam, & a kick, on the A──rse.
S:·Machen 244-206I
